newsitem.title: UK: Britain declines comment on Zimbabwe debt relief.
newsitem.headline: Britain declines comment on Zimbabwe debt relief.

text.p: Britain said it had no comment on a story in Zimbabwe's state-owned Herald newspaper on Tuesday that it was considering cancelling Harare's short-term debt of about Z$288 million ($25.4 million).

A spokeswoman for the Overseas Development Agency said she had no information about a meeting between Zimbabwe Minister of Finance Herbert Murerwa and Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke in London last week.
The Herald said Britain would consider cancelling Zimbabwe's short-term debt if the country came up with a second plan of action for economic reform.
It quoted Murerwa as saying that during bilateral talks in London last week the British government had pledged to support Zimbabwe's privatisation and indigenisation process.
"We discussed the possibility of cancelling our debt and they indicated they are willing to consider it on condition we have a programme for the second phase of the reform programme," said Murerwa.
The paper said the short-term debt amounted to about Z$288 million.

The second phase of reforms, titled the Zimbabwe Programme for Economic and Social Transformation, would be launched this year once a consultation process in government and with industry and labour has been completed. (Z$1 = US$11) -- London newsroom +44 171 542 2734
